questions.text: A 23-year-old male basketball player injured his foot during training and is admitted to the emergency department. An MRI examination reveals a hematoma in the medial malleolus. Upon physical examination the patient shows over eversion of his foot. Which of the following ligaments most likely has a tear?

A newborn baby was diagnosed with eventration of the diaphragm, wherein one half of the diaphragm ascends into the thorax during inspiration, but the other half contracts normally. What is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of musculature in one half of the Diaphragm

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of migration of the diaphragm

options.label: D
options.text: Failure of development of the septum transversum

questions.correct_answer: B. Absence of musculature in one half of the Diaphragm

questions.text: A 65 year old women with a known history of lung cancer comes to hospital due to hoarseness & difficulty in swallowing. She has no disturbance in vision & hearing. On examination there is loss of gag reflex on left side, when the patient is prompted to say “ah”, the uvula deviates to right side. Her left shoulder is drooped & strength is reduced during left shoulder shrug testing. Chest X-ray shows a right lower lobe lung mass & several osteolytic rib lesions. MRI of head also demonstrates multiple lesions consistent with metastasis. A lesion involving which of the anatomical structure is most likely responsible for this patients symptoms ?
Examine the following pic. Which of the following marked nerve is damaged depending on these findings?

Read the Following statements regarding Nerve supply A. Gluteus Maximus – Inferior Gluteal Nerve B. Gluteus Minimus – Superior Gluteal Nerve C. Sartorius – Femoral nerve D. Flexor Digitorum Longus – Tibial Nerve

Assertion (A): The left superior vena cava drains into the right atrium by way of the left sinus horn, that is, the coronary sinus. Reason (R) : Left superior vena cava is caused by persistence of the left anterior cardinal vein and obliteration of the common cardinal and proximal part of the anterior cardinal veins on the right. In such a case, blood from the right is channeled toward the left by way of the brachiocephalic vein.

options.label: A
options.text: Both A and R are true and R is correct explanation of A

options.label: B
options.text: Both A and R are true and R is NOT correct explanation of A

options.label: C
options.text: A is true R is false

options.label: D
options.text: R is true A is false

questions.correct_answer: A. Both A and R are true and R is correct explanation of A

questions.text: Which structure lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis:

A 56-year-old man visited his physician complaining that he experiences severe pain in both legs when taking long walks. He noticed recently that the cramplike pain occurs after walking only a hundred yards. On questioning, he said that the pain quickly disappears on rest only to return after he walks the same distance. When the physician asked about his sex life the patient admitted that he was experiencing difficulty with erection.The symptoms and signs displayed by this patient can be explained by all the following statements except?

options.label: A
options.text: Arteriography of the abdominal aorta revealed blockage in the region of the bifurcation.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the right common iliac artery was involved by disease.

options.label: C
options.text: The gradual blockage of the aorta was caused by advanced arteriosclerosis.

options.label: D
options.text: An insufficient amount of blood was reaching both legs, causing pain (claudication) on walking.

questions.correct_answer: B. Only the right common iliac artery was involved by disease.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has a large intraabdominal mass in the midline just above the pubic symphysis. During surgery a cystic mass is found attached to the umbilicus and to the apex of the bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A male pt. who is married with a child from his wife's previous marriage, presents with inability to have a child in common. He has h/o chronic lower respiratory infections. What does the physician suspect?
A sustained programme of lifting heavy weights will increase bone mass. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this effect of weightlifting?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated metabolic activity stimulates parathyroid hormone secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated metabolic activity stimulates calcitonin secretion

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanical stress on bone increases activity of osteoblasts

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated metabolic activity increases dietary intake of calcium

questions.correct_answer: C. Mechanical stress on bone increases activity of osteoblasts

questions.text: A “birth control” pill for men is being developed for several decades. Which of the following will provide effective sterility in men?

options.label: A
options.text: A compound which mimics the action of LH

options.label: B
options.text: A compound which mimics the action of GnRH

options.label: C
options.text: A compound that blocks the action of Inhibin

options.label: D
options.text: A compound that blocks the action of FSH

questions.correct_answer: D. A compound that blocks the action of FSH

TRPM8 is a TRP channel sensitive to moderate cold and menthol 3. TRPV1 is a vanilloid receptor activated by intense heat, acids and chemicals, such as capsaicin 4. Piezo 1 and Piezo2 are force-activated ion channels that sense touch Use the following key to answer

Shown below are the partial pressure of O2 and CO2 as blood flows from the arterial (Art) to the venous (Ven) end of pulmonary capillaries. Which of the following correctly depicts the changes in Po2 and Pco2 during resting conditions?

Which of the following would be expected to increase the mean systemic filling pressure? a. Increased blood volume b. Increased sympathetic discharge c. Increased venous compliance d. Increased parasympathetic discharge Use the following key to answer

options.label: B
options.text: Options a and b are correct

options.label: C

A healthy 30-year-old woman stand up from the supine position. Which of the following cardiovascular changes are likely in response to standing up from the supine position? a. Increased firing rate of baroreceptors b. Increased sympathetic activity c. Increased parasympathetic activity d. Increased heart rate Use the following key to answer

options.label: A
options.text: Options a, b, c are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Options b and c are correct

options.label: C
options.text: Options b and d are correct

options.label: D
options.text: Options a, b, c and d are all correct

questions.correct_answer: C. Options b and d are correct

Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport: - a. Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into intestinal epithelial cell is by secondary active co-transport b. Transport of glucose into adipocytes is by facilitated diffusion c. Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-dependent counter transport d. Movement of Na++ ions into a nerve cell during the upstroke phase of the action potential is by facilitated diffusion Use the following key to answer

options.label: A
options.text: Options a, b, c are correct

options.label: B
options.text: Options b and c are correct

options.label: C
options.text: Options b and d are correct

options.label: D
options.text: Options a, b, c and d are all correct

questions.correct_answer: A. Options a, b, c are correct

questions.text: Chromosomal mutations can be identified by which all method?

It is well known that DNA polymerases synthesize DNA only in the 5' to 3' direction. Yet, at the replication fork, both strands of parental DNA are being replicated with the synthesis of new DNA. How is it possible that while one strand is being synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction, the other strand appears to be synthesized in the 3' to 5' direction? This apparent paradox is explained by

options.label: D
options.text: Replication and immediate crossover of the leading strand

Following a fad diet meal of skim milk and yogurt, an adult female patient experiences abdominal distention, nausea, cramping, and pain followed by a watery diarrhea. This set of symptoms is observed each time the meal is consumed. A likely diagnosis is
Restriction enzymes have which one of the following characteristics:

options.label: B
options.text: Generate either staggered (sticky) or blunt ends upon cleaving DNA

options.label: D
options.text: Can cleave different DNAs only once

questions.correct_answer: B. Generate either staggered (sticky) or blunt ends upon cleaving DNA

questions.text: Eukaryotic transcription:

options.label: A
options.text: Is independent of the presence of upstream consensus sequences

options.label: B
options.text: May involve a promoter located within the region transcribed rather than upstream.

options.label: C
options.text: Requires a separate promoter region for each of the three ribosomal RNAs transcribed.

options.label: D
options.text: Requires that the entire gene be in the nucleosome from of chromatin RNA polymerase III uses an internal promoter.

questions.correct_answer: B. May involve a promoter located within the region transcribed rather than upstream.

questions.text: Extended matching

A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of recurrent sinusitis that has progressed to a pulmonary infection with left-sided chest pain and fever. One year ago he had an episode of Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia, and he had repeated oral candida infections until a few years ago. He also brought a HPE report as shown in the image. The physician suspects that the patient has an immunodeficiency diseases that results from defective neutrophil destruction of catalase-producing microorganisms. Which of the following would confirm the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Large lysosome vesicles in neutrophils on light microscopy

options.label: B
options.text: Low fluorescent activity on dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry assay

options.label: C
options.text: Low levels of IgM, IgE, and IgA

options.label: D
options.text: Positive nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test

questions.correct_answer: B. Low fluorescent activity on dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry assay

questions.text: A 25 year old biker met an accident while practicing. He underwent splenectomy and during the surgery 2 units of B positive blood transfusion done. After few days he developed fever with chills and rigor. Clinician suspected this as malaria and ordered a peripheral blood examination which confirmed the diagnosis as Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Choose the correct Statement(s) given below regarding this condition. I. There is no Exoerythrocytic cycle in this case II. There is no Pre Erythrocytic cycle in this case. III. There is no erythrocytic cycle in this case IV. Sporozoites are the infective stage in this case V. Trophozoites are the infective stage in this case
questions.correct_answer: B. I, II, V are correct

A 35-year-old man is HIV antibody positive and has a CD4 count of 50/mL. He has had a fever of 101°F for a few weeks and “feels tired all the time.” He has no other symptoms, and findings on physical examination are normal. Complete blood cell count, urinalysis, and chest X-ray are normal. Blood, stool, and urine cultures show no growth. A bone marrow biopsy reveals granulomas, and a culture grows an organism that is a budding yeast at 37°C but produces hyphae at 25°C. The Hyphae morphology shown in the image. Choose the

A 63-year-old male sees his primary care physician for symptoms of fatigue, arthralgia, some nausea, and swelling in his legs. On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. Some yellowing of the skin and eyes is noted. Hepatomegaly is noted on palpitation. Total bilirubin level is determined to be 2.6 mg/dL. Aminotransferase values were three times the upper limit of normal. He is currently on hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He has been married for 41 years to his high school sweetheart. He reports no travel outside of the country. He drinks alcohol rarely and has no history of drug use. He has had no prior hospitalizations and no body piercings. He does have a large tattoo on his left bicep that he received when he was 28 years of age. The clinician ordered hepatitis B viral markers as shown in the List. Choose the correct Statement shows the markers present in the Window Period. I. Anti -HBcAg-IgM, II. Anti-HBcAg – IgG, III. HbsAg, IV. Anti- HBsAg, V. HbeAg, VI. Anti-HBeAg

In the laboratory, a virologist was studying the properties of mutant viruses. When she infected cells with mutant virus A, no progeny viruses were produced. When she infected cells with mutant virus B, no progeny viruses were produced. But when she infected cells with both mutant virus A and mutant virus B, progeny viruses of both virus A and virus B were produced. Which one of the following is the term that best describes this phenomenon?

A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to fever. He returned from a vacation in Goa a week ago and began having symptoms toward the end of his trip. The patient describes continuous fever that has risen slowly to reach a high plateau and is relieved only by antipyretics. He has also had headaches and abdominal discomfort; he initially had constipation but has had loose stools for the past several days. Temperature is 400 C, blood pressure is 114/68 mm Hg, and pulse is 62/min. No oropharyngeal lesions, cervical lymphadenopathy, or neck rigidity is present. Lungs are clear on auscultation, and heart sounds are normal. Abdominal examination shows mild distension and generalized tenderness with hepatosplenomegaly. There is a faint, erythematous, macular skin rash over the trunk and abdomen. Laboratory studies reveal mild, normocytic, normochromic anemia and leukopenia with left shift. Peripheral blood smear is normal. Which of the following is the most likely route of transmission of this patient's infection?

A 48-year-old man comes to the hospital due to 10 days of persistent fever, chills, fatigue, and dyspnea. He had a splenectomy at age 28 after a motor vehicle accident and received the appropriate vaccines. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He recently traveled to Connecticut for a family wedding. His temperature is 38.60 C, blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 108/min. Lung examination reveals coarse crackles. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. A peripheral blood smear shows normocytic, normochromic anemia with ring- and cross-shaped intraerythrocytic inclusions as shown in the image. Thrombocytopenia, elevated LDH, also present. The vector responsible for this patient's current condition can also transmit which of the following organisms?

Few Statements given regarding a Vaccine shown in the Image. Choose the correct Choice which contain the correct statement(s) I. Approved for children < 2 years II. Approved for 2 – 12 years of age group III. Approved for 12 – 18 years of age group IV. Approved for > 18 years of age group

options.label: D
options.text: I, II, III, IV are correct

questions.correct_answer: C. II, III, IV are correct

questions.text: A 6-hour-old boy is evaluated in the newborn nursery due to temperature instability, grunting, and lethargy. The patient was born at full term to a 21-year-old woman who came to the emergency department in active labor with ruptured membranes; she had not received adequate prenatal care. On physical examination,the boy is hypothermic, tachycardic, and tachypnoeic, and he has mottled skin. Blood samples are obtained, and empiric antibiotics are initiated for the treatment of sepsis. Cultures on blood agar grow bacterial colonies with a narrow zone of clear hemolysis. When these bacteria are grown in the presence of Staphylococcus aureus, the zone of hemolysis is enhanced around the staphylococcal colonies. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen infecting this patient?

You are evaluating a journal article describing a test for the diagnosis of congestive heart failure (CHF). In the study described, 250 consecutive patients were given the test. Of the 250 subjects, 100 tested positive tor CHF and 150 tested negative. All 250 subjects were then evaluated by expert cardiologists who were blinded to the results at the experimental test. These cardiologists determined that out of persons who tested positive, 90 actually had CHF. Further, the cardiologists found that of the 150 who tested negative, 20 truly had CHF. What is the positive predictive value (PPV) of this test for the diagnosis of CHF?

The study included 1,000 who took the new drug for 5 years and 1,000 were given the standard therapy. At the end of the trial, 6% of the men in the standard therapy group experienced a stroke, compared to only 2% in the group taking the new drug. Which of the following is true :

options.label: A
options.text: 25 men had to receive the new drug for 5 years in order for one man to benefit (i.e. one less stroke to occur).

options.label: B
options.text: 20 men had to receive the new drug for 5 years in order for one man to benefit

questions.correct_answer: A. 25 men had to receive the new drug for 5 years in order for one man to benefit (i.e. one less stroke to occur).

To his surprise, on the 1st post operative day, the patient's visual acuity was 6/60, there were descment membrane folds with hazy cornea. The anterior chamber was shallow and IOP was 6mm Hg. Siedel test was positive. What could be the reason and management of such situation?

questions.text: A 73-year-old female with a history of well-controlled diabetes recently underwent uncomplicated phacoemulsification with a posterior chamber intraocular lens and complains of blurry vision. Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) is 6/18. Her fluorescein angiogram is given. What is not true?

A 64-year-old Gentleman was admitted with fever, cough and breathlessness. He had developed cough and fever 6 days ago and received Azithromycin for the same. The fever persisted and he became breathless. His saturation was 84% and was rushed to the ER. He is a diabetic, chronic smoker with history of COLD for 5 years on Bronchodilators. On examination, his pulse was 112/min regular with a BP of 100/74 mm of Hg and RR of 40/min. There was central cyanosis/ no clubbing/ no oedema feet. Auscultation revealed bilateral expiratory wheeze. ECG revealed sinus tachycardia. ABG suggested Type 2 respiratory failure. Pro-BNP levels were normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?

65-year-old gentleman presents with episodic palpitations. Patient is a known case of Diabetes on OHA. There is no history of hypertension or cardiac illness in the past. He consumes a quarter of whiskey every night since last 30 years. On examination, he was found to have irregularly irregular rhythm with no radio-femoral delay. The apex-pulse deficit was however present and the deficit was 26 beats/min. What is most probable diagnosis?

A 34-year-old lady presented to the ER with sudden onset palpitations. She gives a history of having similar episodes in the past 3 months. The episodes occur sporadically and each episode last for 10-15 mins. She noticed the need to use the restroom after the episodes. She has no other symptoms, or family history of similar disease. There is history of domestic stressors. She denies use of any OTC medications/recreational drugs. P-154 bpm, BP is 106/70 mm of Hg. ECG was recorded. What would be the first line treatment in this case?

A 76 year –old lady presented to the ER with sudden onset palpitations. She has no other symptoms, or family history of similar disease. She is a known case of hypertension on Amlodipine and takes Atorvastatin for dyslipidaemia. On examination the pulse is 126 bpm, irregularly irregular in rhythm. BP is 124/80mm of Hg and the Spo2 is 98% on Room air. There are no eye signs, no murmurs. ECG was recorded and confirmed Atrial fibrillation with Fast ventricular rate. What is the CHA2DS2Vasc score in this patient?

Theme & Focus : Dementia Lead in Question : For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the cause from the above answer list. Case: 45 years old Male presented with ataxia and urinary incontinence. He has been unwell for 6 months when he developed forgetfulness and was labelled as having dementia. 2 months later he also noticed imbalance while walking. He is obese and smokes 10 cigarettes/day for last 15 years. MRI shows dilatation of ventricles with effacement of sulci and gyri. What is the diagnosis?

Theme & Focus : Dementia Lead in Question : For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the cause from the above answer list. Case : 50 years old male comes with chronic diarrhoea. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. He noticed 6 kgs weight loss in last 3 months and has not taken any multivitamin supplements. He underwent a duodenal biopsy which shows PAS-positive organisms. What is the diagnosis?

Assertion : RA cases have early onset of Osteoarthritis Reason : RA can cause myopathy and osteopenia

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both assertion and reason are independently correct statements but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false statement, but the reason is independently a true statement.

options.label: E
options.text: Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

options.label: B

questions.text: A 54 years old Male, Mountaineer presents with history of progressive breathlessness since last 3 months. He had a trip to Mansarovar 6 months back which was uneventful. HRCT findings are as in the picture. Lung Biopsy shows heterogenous patchy fibrosis with several fibroblastic foci. The most likely diagnosis is:
Following statements about Drug Induced Lupus are True/False:

options.label: C

questions.text: Match the organism associated with risk of auto-immune disease.

A 20-year-old male presented to the clinic with history of fever with chills for past 2 days. He complained of associated headache and myalgia. The highest recorded temperature at home was 41°C and there was no particular pattern. Patient is case of Hereditary Spherocytosis and underwent Splenectomy for the same at 12 years of age since he was transfusion dependant. His vaccination history is complete. On examination he had a Temperature of 40°C, P-90/min, BP-100/60mm of Hg. He had pallor and icterus with no lymphadenopathy. Laboratory tests revealed a Hb-7.3gm/dl, WBC-4600, Plt-94000. His Liver function test showed an elevated bilirubin with elevated ALP, SGOT, SGPT. Urine analysis showed haemoglobinuria and proteinuria. Examination of Giemsa-stained thin smear revealed ameboid trophozoites lacking hemozoin deposits. What is the diagnosis?

A 75-year-old man presents complaining of headache and memory difficulties. He has lost 10 lb since his last office visit 6 months ago. He smoked cigarettes for 40 years but was successful I quitting 10 years ago. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis in his left leg, which was successfully treated by medication. His blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, and his temperature is 101° F (38.3° C). He complains of feeling flushed and of sweating. His laboratory values are as follows: Hct, 60%; WBC, 15,000/mm3; platelets, 400,000/mm3; serum erythropoietin, 0.5 U/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ • The elevated hematocrit level, reduced serum erythropoietin level, headache, fever, memory difficulties, and weight loss seen in this patient are characteristic of polycythemia vera.
  • ↳ • Although there is not an overall consensus on treatment of polycythemia vera, phlebotomy is frequently used as an initial treatment.
  • ↳ • Because this patient is older than 70 years and has previously had a thrombotic event, a myelosuppressive agent such as hydroxyurea should be used in addition to phlebotomy.
  • ↳ • This combination of hydroxyurea and phlebotomy has been demonstrated to be an effective therapeutic regimen in controlling the hematocrit in most patients with polycythemia vera and in lowering the risk of thrombosis that occurs with use of phlebotomy alone.
  • ↳ • When hydroxyurea is used, complete blood counts should be frequently monitored to avoid excessive myelosuppression.
  • ↳ • Patients may experience painful leg ulcers. Two reports have shown an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia in patients taking hydroxyurea, although it remains controversial whether the use of hydroxyurea increases the risk of acute myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?

A 72-year-old male presented with acute onset of lower extremity weakness and numbness for several hours. He has a history of diabetes, peripheral vascular disease, and hypertension. On exam it is noted that the patient has no motor strength in his legs, has lost temperature sensation below his nipples, but has maintained vibratory sensation in his lower extremities. What is the most likely diagnosis?

65-year-old gentleman presented to the neurology clinic with difficulty in recalling and naming common objects. He was feeling distressed and angry with this symptom and hence become withdrawn recently. He had a Left hemisphere stroke 6 months ago leading to right hemiplegia which has gradually improved to power grade 4 with medications and physiotherapy. All the statements about his condition are true except?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a type a mild, fluent aphasia due to damage to the left temporal/parietal lobe

options.label: B
options.text: Patients often use circumlocutions with impaired Repetition and grammatically incorrect sentences.

options.label: C
options.text: Neuro-degenerative diseases may also cause this type of aphasia

options.label: D
options.text: Circumlocution induced naming therapy is helpful in rehabilitation but needs to be continued long-term for consistent results.

questions.correct_answer: B. Patients often use circumlocutions with impaired Repetition and grammatically incorrect sentences.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female is evaluated for recurrent stroke. She is lean, non-diabetic, non-hypertensive and a non-addict. However, cognitive impairment is present on testing. Lipid profile and tests for inherited hyper-coagulable states were normal. She has been on anti-platelets medications with no relief. What is the probable diagnosis?
